questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of hearing loss. He reports difficulty hearing sounds like the beeping of the microwave or birds chirping, but can easily hear the pipe organ at church. He works as an aircraft marshaller. A Rinne test shows air conduction greater than bone conduction bilaterally. A Weber test does not lateralize. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

choices.text: Damage to the organ of Corti

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Perforation of the tympanic membrane causes conductive hearing loss and thus results in an abnormal Rinne test. Tympanic membrane perforation can be caused by foreign body trauma, temporal bone fractures, otitis media, barotrauma, or blast injury. While this patient's occupation puts him at increased risk of damage to the ear, there is nothing in this patient's history to suggest tympanic membrane perforation and the Rinne test was normal, indicating that he does not have conductive hearing loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Immobility of the stapes is the cause of otosclerosis, which can result in conductive hearing loss. The stapes lies against the oval window and transmits sounds from the tympanic membrane. In otosclerosis, the ossicles are rendered immobile by extensive bony remodeling. Patients usually present with bilateral conductive hearing loss and have an abnormal Rinne test. Otosclerosis would not be responsible for the bilateral sensorineural hearing loss seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

External compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve can be caused by tumors such as acoustic neuromas, which are usually unilateral, although they may be bilateral in neurofibromatosis type 2. Compression of this nerve would also result in sensorineural hearing loss. However, acoustic neuromas are usually accompanied by dizziness and ataxia, and they are unlikely to cause isolated symmetrical high-frequency hearing loss. Given this patient's history of chronic exposure to loud noises, a different etiology of his hearing loss is much more likely.

D) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the oval window is a cause of hearing loss associated with barotrauma. Sudden decreases in pressure between the inner and outer ear cause dissolved gasses to be released from the perilymphatic fluid in the inner ear and results in rupture of the oval window. Patients with barotrauma will have a recent history of diving or flying, which this patient does not. In addition, the sensorineural hearing loss resulting from rupture of the oval window is not limited to high-frequency sounds.

E) CORRECT:

NIHL is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells of the organ of Corti. In a normally functioning ear, sound waves are transmitted mechanically through the tympanic membrane, via the ossicles, and through the oval window to the perilymph-filled inner ear. The resulting vibrations are transmitted to the cochlear hair cells, from where neurologic impulses are transmitted via the vestibulocochlear nerve. Repeated exposure to sounds louder than 85 dB, like those this man experiences at work, can damage the hair cells of the organ of Corti and result in subsequent sensorineural hearing loss that typically affects high-frequency hearing first. Additionally, exposure to sudden, extremely loud noise greater than 120 dB can lead to the rupture of the tympanic membrane, which would cause conductive hearing loss.
Image Description:

Audiogram of a young adult

There is a bilateral reduction in air and bone conduction as 4000 Hz.

This finding is typical of noise-induced sensorineural hearing loss

F) INCORRECT:

Excess endolymphatic fluid pressure resulting in sensorineural hearing loss is seen in Meniere disease. Symptoms are usually unilateral and typically include hearing loss, aural fullness, episodic vertigo, and tinnitus, none of which are present in this patient. Additionally, the sensorineural hearing loss in Meniere disease usually affects lower-frequency sounds and is unilateral. The patient described in this case has high-frequency hearing loss that is bilateral, as suggested by the absence of lateralization on the Weber test.
questions.hint: Bilateral high-frequency hearing loss in a patient with occupational noise exposure should raise concern for noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL). The absence of lateralization on Weber tests suggests that both ears are equally affected, while the normal Rinne test suggests that the hearing loss is sensorineural in origin.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man comes to the veterans’ administration outpatient clinic because of ringing in his ears and worsening difficulty hearing. He has had gradually increasing difficulties hearing conversations in crowded places, which he first noticed 3 years ago. He has also felt depressed, and he noticed that he regularly thinks back to his time in the military. The patient retired from the military 1 month ago when he returned from a deployment to Syria where he was involved in active combat. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His vital signs are within normal limits. Otoscopic examination shows a clear translucent tympanic membrane with a normal light reflex. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the right mastoid process. Immediately after the patient stops hearing a tone, the tuning fork is held over the right ear and he reports hearing the tuning fork again. The same test is repeated on the left side and shows the same pattern. The vibrating tuning fork is then placed on the middle of the forehead and the patient hears the sound in the center of his head. The results of an audiogram are shown. Mental status examination shows a depressed mood. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's impaired hearing?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ototoxic medications such as loop diuretics, aminoglycosides, vancomycin, or cisplatin can cause tinnitus and bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss, which are present here. However, this patient's only current medication is hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, which is not known to be ototoxic.

B) INCORRECT:

Meniere disease, which is caused by endolymphatic hydrops, can lead to tinnitus and bilateral sensorineural hearing loss, both of which are seen here. However, in initial stages, the hearing loss in this condition would usually have a fluctuating course, be accompanied by a sensation of ear fullness, and primarily affect low frequencies. In addition, Meniere disease typically manifests with acute episodes of severe peripheral vertigo (a component of the Meniere triad). In contrast, this patient does not report vertigo or ear fullness and has progressive high-frequency hearing loss, while Meniere disease typically causes low to mid-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.
Image Description:

Audiograms of a patient with Meniere disease in the left ear

Left audiogram (at first presentation): normal hearing in both ears

Right audiogram (2 years later): sensorineural hearing loss to low and midfrequency signals in the left ear; normal hearing in the right ear

Asymmetric fluctuating sensorineural hearing loss is a characteristic feature of Meniere disease.

Circle: hearing threshold of the right ear; Square: hearing threshold of the left ear

C) INCORRECT:

Otosclerosis, which leads to fixation of the stapes bone in the oval window, can affect both ears and cause progressive bilateral hearing loss and tinnitus, as seen here. However, the hearing loss in this condition is conductive rather than sensorineural; therefore, a negative rather than positive Rinne test would be expected. Moreover, patients with otosclerosis hear better in crowded environments (paracusis willisii) and have a characteristic notched hearing loss at 2 kHz (Carhart notch) on an audiogram unlike this patient who has difficulty hearing in crowded places and a notch at 3–4 kHz. Additionally, otoscopic examination in patients with active otosclerosis would usually reveal a red-blue hue seen through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign) as opposed to a clear, translucent tympanic membrane with a normal light reflex.
Image Description:

Audiogram of a patient with otosclerosis in the right ear.

Air conduction is reduced in the affected ear by approx. 35dB. Bone conduction shows a characteristic notched hearing loss at 2000Hz (Carhart notch). These are characteristic findings of otosclerosis, a condition that causes conductive hearing loss due to the fixation of the stapes to the oval window.

D) INCORRECT:

Presbycusis is the most common type of sensorineural hearing loss. This condition leads to progressive bilateral hearing loss with impairment of high-frequency hearing and tinnitus, both of which are seen here. However, presbycusis is usually first noticed in the sixth decade of life and the audiogram shows hearing impairment across a wide spectrum of high frequencies rather than a pronounced notch at a specific frequency.
Image Description:

Frequency-dependent auditory threshold, measured via air and bone conduction: In presbycusis, patients struggle to hear the higher frequencies in both air and bone conduction.

E) INCORRECT:

Ear barotrauma can be caused by flying or explosions (blast injuries), both of which this patient has likely been exposed to, and can lead to bilateral sensorineural hearing loss and tinnitus. However, sensorineural hearing loss in this condition results from rupture of the oval window membrane and would be accompanied by nausea and vertigo. More commonly, barotrauma manifests with conductive hearing loss, which would show a different pattern on tuning fork tests and audiogram. In addition, symptom onset is sudden rather than progressive and affected patients typically present with a feeling of pressure and/or stabbing ear pain. Finally, otoscopic examination would reveal hematotympanum as opposed to a clear, translucent tympanic membrane with a normal light reflex.

F) CORRECT:

Repeated exposure to sounds above a threshold of 85 dB (e.g., motorcycle) or a single exposure to sounds above 120 dB (e.g., gunshots, jet takeoffs) can lead to noise-induced hearing loss. Sensorineural hearing loss is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of the hair cells in the organ of Corti. Deployed military personnel, like this patient, have a high occupational risk of developing noise-induced hearing loss. Such hearing loss is slowly progressive and affects high frequencies (3–4 kHz) first, which results in difficulty hearing in crowded environments. Tinnitus is often an associated symptom. There is no definitive treatment available (besides hearing aids); therefore, prevention with appropriate hearing protection is essential. In addition to sensorineural hearing loss, exposure to sudden noise louder than 120 dB can cause conductive hearing loss through rupture of the tympanic membrane.

Hearing loss is a risk factor for depressive disorders, which are common among veterans.
questions.hint: A bilaterally positive Rinne test and absent lateralization of sound during the Weber test in a patient with difficulty hearing indicate bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His difficulty hearing conversations in crowded places is suggestive of high-frequency hearing loss, which is evident on the audiogram (notch between 3–4 kHz).

questions.text:
A 46-year-old male military veteran who served in Operation Iraqi Freedom and Operation New Dawn presents after progressive dyspnea prevented him from completing the 2-mile run for his physical fitness readiness. He has never smoked and has no significant medical history or family history of lung disease, cardiovascular disease, or sudden cardiac death. He reports that his dyspnea on exertion started when he was in Iraq; it has persisted since he returned from deployment one year ago. Now, he is unable to pass his physical fitness readiness test.
On physical examination, the patient is not in acute distress. His temperature is 36.8°C, his blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg, his pulse is 62 beats per minute, his respiratory rate is 13 breaths per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 96% while he is breathing ambient air. Chest auscultation and cardiac examination are normal.
A chest radiograph is normal, but high-resolution chest CT is notable for diffuse, but mild, centrilobular nodules and airway thickening.
Which one of the following diagnoses should be considered in the evaluation of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

More than 2 million U.S. military men and women were deployed to Iraq during Operation Iraqi Freedom, Operation New Dawn, or both — or to Afghanistan during Operation Enduring Freedom. These deployments were associated with exposure to potentially hazardous inhalants, including burn-pit combustion products, desert dusts, explosive blasts, local polluting industries, and microbial aerosols. A case series showed that a substantial number of these military personnel are at risk for constrictive bronchiolitis. In constrictive bronchiolitis, bronchial wall changes lead to narrowing of the air lumina resulting in airflow obstruction.

Key learning point: The condition that must be considered in the differential diagnosis of dyspnea on exertion in a military veteran previously deployed to Iraq during Operation Iraqi Freedom, Operation New Dawn, or both — or to Afghanistan during Operation Enduring Freedom — is constrictive bronchiolitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage has not been associated with deployment to these regions, and affected patients have diffuse ground-glass opacities on chest imaging.

C) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis has also not been associated with deployment to these regions. Radiographic features of this condition include the peripheral lower-lobe-predominant reticular changes and honeycombing that are sometimes associated with traction bronchiectasis.

D) INCORRECT:

Acute eosinophilic pneumonia, but not chronic eosinophilic pneumonia, has been described following deployment to Iraq and Afghanistan.

E) INCORRECT:

Although a number of military personnel have reported anxiety during and following deployment, pulmonary etiologies should be considered first when evaluating dyspnea, especially given the subtle abnormalities on chest CT scan.

A Rinne test shows air conduction greater than bone conduction bilaterally. A Weber test does not lateralize. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's condition?

There is a bilateral reduction in air and bone conduction as 4000 Hz.

This finding is typical of noise-induced sensorineural hearing loss

The absence of lateralization on Weber tests suggests that both ears are equally affected, while the normal Rinne test suggests that the hearing loss is sensorineural in origin.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man comes to your clinic for evaluation of hearing loss. He reports difficulty hearing high-pitched sounds such as the beeping of the microwave or birds chirping, but can easily hear lower-pitched sounds like the pipe organ at church. He works as an aircraft marshaller. On examination, a Rinne test shows air conduction greater than bone conduction bilaterally, and a Weber test does not lateralize. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his condition?

choices.text: Damage to the organ of Corti.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

NIHL is caused by irreversible damage to the stereocilia of hair cells of the organ of Corti. In a normally functioning ear, sound waves are transmitted mechanically through the tympanic membrane, via the ossicles, and through the oval window to the perilymph-filled inner ear. The resulting vibrations are transmitted to the cochlear hair cells, from where neurologic impulses are transmitted via the vestibulocochlear nerve. Repeated exposure to sounds louder than 85 dB, like those this man experiences at work, can damage the hair cells of the organ of Corti and result in subsequent sensorineural hearing loss that typically affects high-frequency hearing first. Additionally, exposure to sudden, extremely loud noise greater than 120 dB can lead to the rupture of the tympanic membrane, which would cause conductive hearing loss.

Key learning point: Noise-induced hearing loss is caused by irreversible damage to the hair cells of the organ of Corti, typically resulting in high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss.
Image Description:

Audiogram of a young adult

There is a bilateral reduction in air and bone conduction as 4000 Hz.

This finding is typical of noise-induced sensorineural hearing loss

B) INCORRECT:

Perforation of the tympanic membrane causes conductive hearing loss and thus results in an abnormal Rinne test. Tympanic membrane perforation can be caused by foreign body trauma, temporal bone fractures, otitis media, barotrauma, or blast injury. While this patient's occupation puts him at increased risk of damage to the ear, there is nothing in this patient's history to suggest tympanic membrane perforation and the Rinne test was normal, indicating that he does not have conductive hearing loss.

C) INCORRECT:

Immobility of the stapes is the cause of otosclerosis, which can result in conductive hearing loss. The stapes lies against the oval window and transmits sounds from the tympanic membrane. In otosclerosis, the ossicles are rendered immobile by extensive bony remodeling. Patients usually present with bilateral conductive hearing loss and have an abnormal Rinne test. Otosclerosis would not be responsible for the bilateral sensorineural hearing loss seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

External compression of the vestibulocochlear nerve can be caused by tumors such as acoustic neuromas, which are usually unilateral, although they may be bilateral in neurofibromatosis type 2. Compression of this nerve would also result in sensorineural hearing loss. However, acoustic neuromas are usually accompanied by dizziness and ataxia, and they are unlikely to cause isolated symmetrical high-frequency hearing loss. Given this patient's history of chronic exposure to loud noises, a different etiology of his hearing loss is much more likely.

E) INCORRECT:

Rupture of the oval window is a cause of hearing loss associated with barotrauma. Sudden decreases in pressure between the inner and outer ear cause dissolved gasses to be released from the perilymphatic fluid in the inner ear and results in rupture of the oval window. Patients with barotrauma will have a recent history of diving or flying, which this patient does not. In addition, the sensorineural hearing loss resulting from rupture of the oval window is not limited to high-frequency sounds.

The absence of lateralization on Weber tests suggests that both ears are equally affected, while the normal Rinne test suggests that the hearing loss is sensorineural in origin.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man who is a construction worker presents to the emergency department with a 2-year history of progressive dyspnea and dry cough. He has worked in construction for 25 years, including renovation projects on older buildings. Chest x-ray is shown. Which exposure is most likely responsible?

choices.text: Asbestos fiber exposure from insulation work
Beryllium exposure from removing telecommunications equipment
Irritant gas exposure from epoxy resins
Lead particle exposure from paint removal
Silica dust exposure from grinding countertops

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Asbestosis causes respiratory symptoms but typically manifests with bilateral lower lobe changes rather than the upper lobe nodular pattern seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Beryllium exposure may trigger sarcoidosis, but sarcoidosis typically manifests with bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy rather than bilateral upper lobe nodular opacities.

C) INCORRECT:

Irritant gas exposure typically causes acute respiratory symptoms rather than the chronic progressive dyspnea and characteristic radiographic changes seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

This patient's chest x-ray findings and isolated respiratory symptoms are atypical for lead exposure.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – The diffuse upper lobe nodules, fibrosis, and hilar lymphadenopathy are characteristic of silicosis, which can occur in construction workers who grind countertops.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of bilateral wrist pain and morning stiffness. She has worked as a data entry clerk for the same company for 5 years without previous issues. Her symptoms began 2 weeks after she switched from part-time to full-time data entry work following a departmental restructuring. The pain is worse during her work shifts and improves on weekends. Which finding represents a red flag for occupational injury?

choices.text: Five years of employment at same company
Symptoms began after job change to full-time work

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Bilateral wrist symptoms occur in many occupational and nonoccupational conditions, including carpal tunnel syndrome and rheumatoid arthritis. The bilateral nature of symptoms alone does not constitute a red flag for occupational injury.

B) INCORRECT:

Morning stiffness is a common symptom that can accompany various musculoskeletal conditions, including inflammatory arthritis and overuse injuries. This symptom pattern alone is not a specific red flag that suggests occupational causation.

C) INCORRECT:

Length of employment is not a red flag for occupational injury. Workers can develop both occupational and nonoccupational conditions at any point during their employment, and the duration of employment does not indicate increased or decreased likelihood of workplace causation.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – Symptom onset after a job change is a specific red flag for occupational injury. This temporal relationship suggests that new or increased workplace factors may be contributing to the development of symptoms, warranting further occupational assessment.

E) INCORRECT:

Demographic characteristics such as gender and work environment type are not red flags for occupational injury.

questions.text: A 35-year-old warehouse worker is brought to the emergency department 45 minutes after exposure to spilled industrial cleaning solutions. The patient is being evaluated in the resuscitation area. Paramedics report they are hemodynamically stable with mild respiratory symptoms. The patient's clothing has been removed, and they are in a hospital gown. What is the most important next management step?

choices.text: Ensure all healthcare staff don appropriate personal protective equipment
Order chest x-ray and complete metabolic panel to assess for systemic effects
Obtain material safety data sheets from the employer before proceeding
Contact the local health department to report the workplace exposure incident
Begin empiric treatment with activated charcoal and gastric lavage

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Secondary contamination poses significant occupational health risks to healthcare workers. Industrial chemicals can persist on skin, hair, and personal effects despite initial decontamination efforts. Volatile emissions from residual chemical deposits and direct contact during patient examination create ongoing exposure pathways that require barrier protection throughout the encounter.

B) INCORRECT:

Standard laboratory studies and imaging lack sensitivity for detecting early toxicological effects from most industrial chemicals. Many cleaning solutions contain volatile organic compounds or caustic agents that produce delayed systemic manifestations, making immediate testing of limited diagnostic value. Exposure-specific testing would be more clinically relevant once the chemical identity is confirmed. In the initial stages of evaluation, basic measures for patient and staff safety are a higher priority.

C) INCORRECT:

Material safety data sheets (MSDS) provide essential toxicological data, including chemical composition, acute exposure effects, and specific antidotal therapy recommendations. However, they may not be readily available, as this depends on employer availability and cooperation, and their utility may be limited if the identity of the exposed substance is uncertain or if the products contain proprietary formulations that are not fully disclosed in the MSDS. So while it is a helpful component of the toxicological risk assessment for industrial chemical exposures, initial management should not be delayed to obtain an MSDS. Once a reliable MSDS is available, clinicians should still correlate features of the patient's poisoning with the expected toxicity described in the MSDS to see if these align before acting on that information.

D) INCORRECT:

Regulatory notification serves important epidemiological surveillance functions and may identify workplace hazards affecting multiple workers. While legally mandated under OSHA standards, these reporting requirements typically allow 8–24 hours for initial notification. The priority for this patient is immediate care and staff safety measures.

E) INCORRECT:

Empiric gastrointestinal decontamination techniques are not advisable in industrial exposures. GI decontamination is typically contraindicated in caustic exposures due to the risk of reinjury during emesis, and it lacks efficacy for dermal or inhalational exposures. Industrial cleaning solutions typically contain surfactants, solvents, or alkaline compounds that do not respond to activated charcoal adsorption and may cause additional mucosal injury if gastric lavage is attempted. In contrast, body surface decontamination methods may be indicated.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man who is a construction worker presents to the emergency department with altered mental status after working in a confined space. His coworkers report that he was applying pesticides and was found unconscious 30 minutes ago. Vital signs are BP, 85/50; P, 55; R, 28; oxygen saturation, 92% on room air. Physical examination shows excessive salivation, muscle fasciculations, and bilateral wheezing. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pralidoxime is an oxime that reactivates acetylcholinesterase and is used as an adjunct to atropine in organophosphate poisoning. However, pralidoxime should be administered with or shortly after atropine initiation, as oximes may transiently increase acetylcholinesterase inhibition when used alone.

B) INCORRECT:

Naloxone is the antidote for opioid poisoning, which typically manifests with respiratory depression, miosis, and altered mental status but lacks the characteristic cholinergic features of excessive secretions, muscle fasciculations, and bronchospasm seen in organophosphate poisoning.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with cholinergic toxidrome from organophosphate poisoning, evidenced by the combination of muscarinic symptoms (bradycardia, hypotension, excessive salivation, bronchospasm) and nicotinic effects (muscle fasciculations). Atropine acts as a competitive inhibitor of muscarinic receptors and should be initiated as quickly as possible. The initial dose is 1–3 mg IV in adults, with doses doubled and repeated every 5 minutes until heart rate exceeds 80 bpm, systolic blood pressure exceeds 80 mm Hg, and the chest sounds clear.

D) INCORRECT:

While respiratory failure is the leading cause of death in cholinergic poisoning and mechanical ventilation may eventually be required, the initial priority is antidotal therapy with atropine to reverse the muscarinic effects. Early intubation should be considered in patients with muscle weakness to reduce aspiration risk.

E) INCORRECT:

Activated charcoal may be considered for recent oral ingestion of organophosphates in intubated patients but is not the initial priority. The immediate focus should be on antidotal therapy with atropine to reverse the life-threatening cholinergic crisis and prevent respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 29-year-old factory worker presents 10 minutes after inhalational exposure to vapors from a spilled industrial chemical. He reports mild throat burning and headache. Physical examination shows normal vital signs, oxygen saturation 98% on room air, and no respiratory distress. Paramedics were told by coworkers that the exposure involved an industrial adhesive, but the chemical container could not be retrieved from the spill site due to safety concerns. Staff have donned appropriate personal protective equipment. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Contact the regional poison control center for guidance
Contact the adhesive manufacturer's emergency hotline
Interview coworkers about previous similar exposures
Notify the workplace safety officer to report the incident
Obtain material safety data sheets for the adhesive

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Poison control centers can provide valuable consultation, but with only the general information that this was an "industrial adhesive," their guidance would be limited to general supportive measures rather than chemical-specific treatment recommendations.

B) INCORRECT:

Without knowing the specific manufacturer or product name, contacting a manufacturer's emergency hotline would be impossible. Even if the manufacturer were identified, this process typically takes time to connect with appropriate personnel.

C) INCORRECT:

Coworker interviews may provide some context, but likely cannot provide the specific chemical composition or toxicological information needed to guide immediate treatment decisions. While some experienced workers may know the chemical makeup of industrial products they handle, it is unreasonable to assume they know the effects of specific substances following a toxic exposure.

D) INCORRECT:

While workplace notification is important for regulatory compliance and preventing further exposures, direct patient care should take priority over administrative reporting tasks. Incident reporting can be completed after patient evaluation and treatment decisions are made.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – Material safety data sheets provide immediate access to the specific chemical composition, health hazards, and recommended treatment measures for the exact adhesive used at this workplace. This information is essential for determining appropriate management, potential complications to monitor for, and whether specific antidotes or interventions are indicated. The workplace should have MSDS readily available for all chemicals on-site, making this the most direct route to obtain treatment-specific information.

questions.text: Four employees from a local metal-finishing plant present to the ED after exposure to a degreasing solvent that splashed during cleaning. They report eye irritation, mild dyspnea, and nausea. Staff note a chemical odor and visible residue on their clothing. The patients are currently in the triage area. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Proceed with clinical evaluation using standard precautions while maintaining good room ventilation
Move patients directly to negative-pressure isolation rooms for comprehensive assessment
Observe patients in a dedicated area for delayed symptoms while awaiting guidance from poison control
Direct patients to decontamination area, remove contaminated clothing, and clean affected surfaces
Obtain material safety data sheets from the employer before initiating any intervention

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Standard precautions alone are insufficient when chemical contamination is suspected. While enhanced ventilation may reduce vapor accumulation in enclosed spaces, it does not address the primary hazard of contact transfer from contaminated clothing and skin surfaces. The presence of visible residue and chemical odor indicates active contamination requiring immediate surface decontamination to prevent secondary exposure to healthcare personnel and other patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Negative-pressure rooms are designed for airborne pathogen control, not chemical decontamination scenarios. Moving patients with visible chemical contamination into interior hospital spaces without prior decontamination violates fundamental hazmat protocols and risks widespread environmental contamination. The solvent residue on clothing and skin poses ongoing exposure risks that room ventilation cannot adequately address.

C) INCORRECT:

Clinical observation has merit for detecting delayed toxicity, but deferring decontamination while contaminated materials remain in contact with patients and the environment creates unnecessary exposure risks. Poison control consultation provides valuable guidance on substance-specific management, but should complement rather than delay basic decontamination measures. The combination of symptoms and visible contamination indicates that immediate decontamination is warranted.

D) CORRECT:

Correct — Surface decontamination takes priority when patients present with visible chemical contamination and compatible clinical symptoms. Removing contaminated clothing and washing exposed areas prevents continued dermal absorption and protects healthcare workers from secondary exposure. This approach aligns with the exposure phase of the ABCDE toxicological assessment and should be completed before patients enter main patient care areas.

E) INCORRECT:

Material safety data sheets provide critical information about chemical properties, toxicity, and specific treatment recommendations. However, basic decontamination principles apply broadly to unknown industrial solvents and should not be delayed pending documentation review. The presence of symptoms, odor, and visible residue creates an immediate hazard requiring prompt intervention. Documentation review can proceed simultaneously with decontamination efforts.

questions.text: Two workers present to the ED after a spill involving a corrosive cleaning solvent. They were briefly rinsed at the worksite but still have chemical residue on exposed skin and clothing. Both are alert and hemodynamically stable. Which decontamination approach is most appropriate before proceeding with further evaluation and treatment?

choices.text: Apply cold compresses to affected areas to limit chemical penetration, then rinse with hot water to enhance removal
Delay body surface decontamination and irrigation until the material safety data sheet is obtained
Remove all clothing, brush off dry particles, and irrigate exposed skin and hair with water
Cover contaminated areas with sterile moist dressings and await poison control center guidance before irrigation
Use neutralizing agents or acidic/alkaline buffers based on the identified substance's pH

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This approach is contraindicated because cold compresses delay immediate decontamination, allowing continued chemical contact time and tissue penetration. Hot water irrigation can worsen chemical burns by enhancing the corrosive effects of many substances and potentially causing thermal injury in addition to chemical injury. The fundamental principle in chemical exposure is immediate, copious room-temperature water irrigation to physically remove and dilute contaminants, not temperature-based interventions that delay this critical step.

B) INCORRECT:

While material safety data sheets provide valuable toxicological information, delaying decontamination to obtain documentation allows continued chemical contact time, increasing tissue penetration and systemic absorption. The fundamental principle in toxicological emergencies is that time to intervention directly correlates with outcome severity. Water irrigation is universally safe for most chemical exposures except for rare exceptions like elemental metals or dry lime powder.

C) CORRECT:

Correct — This represents the evidence-based triad of effective chemical decontamination: immediate complete disrobing prevents continued exposure from contaminated clothing, mechanical particle removal eliminates concentrated chemical deposits that water alone cannot dissolve, and copious water irrigation (10–15 minutes minimum) physically removes residual agents while diluting remaining contaminants. This approach minimizes both patient injury and healthcare worker secondary exposure.

D) INCORRECT:

Covering contaminated skin can create an occlusive environment that enhances percutaneous absorption through increased skin hydration and temperature, the opposite of desired decontamination goals. Anything prolonging skin contact time can worsen chemical injury. While poison control consultation is valuable for complex cases, it should not delay life-saving interventions that emergency physicians can perform independently.

E) INCORRECT:

Chemical neutralization is rarely indicated in the ED because exothermic reactions can aggravate burns. Additionally, neutralization often produces secondary toxic products or gases. Water irrigation remains the safest and most effective initial management for nearly all exposures.
